results.title: Why Are Young People Pretending to Love Work?
results.abstract: I saw the greatest minds of my generation log 18-hour days — and then boast about #hustle on Instagram. When did performative workaholism become a lifestyle?

results.title: A Tiny Screw Shows Why iPhones Won’t Be ‘Assembled in U.S.A.’
results.abstract: Apple decided several years ago to produce a high-end Mac in Texas. The problems that surfaced illustrate the challenges of domestic manufacturing.

results.byline: By NOAM SCHEIBER and JOHN ELIGON
results.title: Elite Law Firm’s All-White Partner Class Stirs Debate on Diversity
results.abstract: Paul, Weiss is more diverse at its top ranks than most of its peers. But its recent promotions underscored how far big firms have to go to elevate women and people of color.

media.caption: A LinkedIn post announcing the latest class of partners at Paul, Weiss prompted a social media firestorm over its overwhelmingly white, male profile.

results.title: Your 2019 Tax Refund Might Be Higher, Lower or Later Than Usual
results.abstract: It’s unclear how the Trump tax law will affect refunds in what has been a clockwork injection of cash into the economy. The shutdown’s effects are murkier still.

media.caption: While furloughed federal workers will return to their jobs on Monday, it will take time to get parts of the I.R.S. running smoothly again.

results.title: These Patients Had Sickle-Cell Disease. Experimental Therapies Might Have Cured Them.
results.abstract: Success against sickle-cell would be “the first genetic cure of a common genetic disease” and could free tens of thousands of Americans from agonizing pain.

media.caption: Brandon Williams received gene therapy to replace sickle cells with healthy hemoglobin. His sister, Britney, died of complications of sickle-cell disease. He has a tattoo of her name on his right arm.
